og_description: In the second half of the 20th century, the famous linguist Noam Chomsky proposed that there is a common structure to all of the world's languages, from English to Japanese. He called it a 'universal grammar'. But is there is really a universal grammar? Vieri Samek-Lodovici thinks so and explains not only how to make sense of the idea but also how it has been developed in recent years.
